user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_connection_values:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN int
MHD_get_connection_values (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                           enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                           MHD_KeyValueIterator iterator,
                           void *iterator_cls)
{
  int ret;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return -1;
  ret = 0;
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    if (0 != (pos->kind & kind))
    {
      ret++;
      if ( (NULL != iterator) &&
           (MHD_NO == iterator (iterator_cls,
                                pos->kind,
                                pos->header,
                                pos->value)) )
        return ret;
    }
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
explanation: Other fragments in the function (declarations: "int ret; struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;", and the simple assignment "ret = 0;") do not need investigation for unreachable-code under MISRA Rule 2.1 because they are straightforward declarations/initializations with no conditional or constant-control-flow that would make them statically unreachable. There are no constant expressions or unconditional jumps preceding them that would render those lines dead. The items selected above are the control-flow points that can lead to early exits or skipped blocks depending on runtime state (NULL connection, emptiness of the headers list, the bit-test on pos->kind, the optional iterator call and its return value) and therefore should be investigated for possible unreachable-code violations.
